Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Household Decision-Making and Child Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to broaden understanding of the cognitive development of children using a modeling framework that allows to incorporate direct measures of investment activity by parents, children, and schools in the production of the child's cognitive ability from birth through adolescence. The first project studies the transition of investment in child cognitive ability from the parents to the child over the development phase. The factors driving the transition include: the increased productivity of self-investment as the child ages; increases in the child's future orientation (reflected in age-specific discount factors that are increasing in age); and (exogenous and endogenous) changes in the child's role in household decision-making. The PIs will formulate and estimate both non-cooperative and cooperative models of interactions between parents and children.

The second project investigates the role of formal schooling in the cognitive development process. As observed in the Child Development Supplement data from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics, time spent with children declines dramatically (particularly for mothers) when children begin formal schooling. Within the modeling framework, schooling is viewed as a new "factor of production" that enters the child production function when the child first enters formal schooling. Jointly modeling both school and parental inputs is an important contribution to a literature which largely considers each in isolation. The CDS-PSID contains information not only on the geographic location of sample respondents, but also specific information on the quality of the school that each child attends.

Understanding the cognitive development process and the role that various actors play in it is essential for the formulation of effective policies to achieve better developmental outcomes. The PIs will use estimates from these models to perform comparative statics exercises and counterfactual policy experiments that have the potential to inform policy, such as the efficacy of parental leaves or the design of effective unconditional and conditional cash transfer (CCT) programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research has been focused on understanding the interactions between parents and children and their implication for the cognitive development of children. We study the growth of cognitive ability, measured by scores on standard cognitive tests, as determined by the choices made by parents and children. From our previous research on the subject, we know that the time that parents spend interacting with their children is a very important determinant of the growth in the child's ability, much more so than are their money expenditures on the children. We have extended this framework to consider the impact of the child's time investment in herself (e.g., study time) on her rate of cognitive development. Using nationally representative survey data recording the detailed interactions of all adults and other with children along with in-depth measures of cognitive development, we find that the child’s own study time is an important input, the importance of which grows with age. 

In our models, we studied the complex interactions between parents and children. In a departure from standard economic models of the household, our models recognize that there may be varying degrees of conflict and cooperation between parents and their children. In many households, parents want their children to study more, and therefore need to find a way to incentivize their children through rewards to pay for studying or good grades. Not all households can do this however, and our estimation results indicate that wealthier parents are more likely to utilize such incentives. The constraints faced by poor households then has important implications for the transmission of inequality across generations.

We have also studied the impact on child development of various forms of monetary transfers to households with children, typically from a government agency, such as with tax subsidies to larger families. We studied two types of transfers that are unconditional, that is, the household receives them no matter what the level of their child's cognitive ability (as measured by test scores). One type of unconditional cash transfer (UCT) places no restrictions on how the money should be spent by the household, while the other only allows it to be spent on the child. The third system we studied are conditional cash transfers (CCT), in which the household only receives the cash transfer if their child's measured cognitive ability was greater than a certain threshold. We compared the performance of these various transfer systems in terms of their cost of achieving a pre-specified improvement in the average cognitive ability of children of a certain age. We found that the CCT system was vastly more cost-effective than were the UCT systems. This is offset, to some degree, by the greater cost of implementing a CCT system.

Most of our research applied to households in which both biological parents are present, but we know that a large proportion of children grow up in households with one, or even both, biological parents absent. In one branch of our research, we have investigated how the family law environment, that is, rules about whether only one or both spouses must agree to a divorce and child support awards and custody/visitation arrangements when a child is present, impact the decisions to have a child, how much to invest in the child, and whether to divorce. Among parents who divorce, we found that their child suffers decreases in cognitive outcomes prior to the divorce and immediately following it, but that there is catch-up period after the divorce. We also found that changes in the family law environment that tend to favor one spouse over the other tend not to have large effects on children's cognitive ability, but they do have appreciable negative effects on the fertility rate.

In other research, we have studied in more detail the particular test scores used to measure children’s cognitive development. In a series of papers, we provide new methodological and empirical results connecting the typical test score measures, which can often be error prone or “noisy,” with the actual development of children. We are also currently extending our research to explicitly incorporate the importance of schooling, recognizing that schools and classrooms can vary widely in their effectiveness.

And, as an integral part of our research program, we have trained a number of Ph.D. students, who have gone on to conduct their own research on child development. They are extending our analysis in several important directions including research on welfare programs, the influence of peers, birth order differences, and air pollution effects on cognitive development.
